speaker: Teacher
text: Okay, so usually we... We have an introduction track explaining the method and the project, but I suspected we might be losing quite a few, uh, learners this way so we can just jump right into learning French. I do need to tell you a little bit about how we're going to learn though, and that's just basically that you need to relax and simply follow this conversation that we're having like you would with a friend, just that now that friend is me. And when I ask you something, you will think it out and reply as you would in any other conversation. I'll be speaking to a real student. Hello.

speaker: Teacher
text: [laughs] Who is here with me. And you should get in the habit of replying when he does. And any other advice that you might need to follow the course will be given as we go along. I wanted to begin by speaking about how, in English, we already use a lot of French in English. English is a language, it's kind of half Germanic and half Latin. Somewhere there in the middle. You know, a lot of the time we have two words to say the same thing, and one sounds formal and the other one sounds informal. And you know, one is... The formal one is Latin and the informal one is Germanic. You know, you could have, for example, "to ask," which is very Germanic, and then "to inquire," you know, which is very Latin. That Latin word is often going to sound like a French word. So we already speak or use a lot of French in our English, even though we may not realize it. For example, the word for "cake" in French is "gâteau."

speaker: Teacher
text: "Gâteau." And of course, we have this in English, no? But in English, "gateau" describes a type of cake. In French, it's just the everyday word for "cake," "gâteau," or "the cake," "le," "le gâteau."

speaker: Teacher
text: "Le gâteau." Or we have the word "coffee" in English, which is "café" in French, "café." Meaning both "coffee" or "a coffee shop," you know, like where you go to drink coffee.

speaker: Teacher
text: So if "le gâteau" is "the cake," "le gâteau," how might you say "the coffee"?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Le café," very good. So for the students listening to the recording, you would've had a second or two pause there to respond like the student here with me and say, "Le café." But you should get in the habit of pausing, even though you might not need to yet, you should get in the habit of pausing, thinking out slowly and calmly your response, saying it out loud, and then continuing to see what the student here with me has said. And in this way, participate in the class. "I want," in French, "I want," is "je veux."

speaker: Teacher
text: "Je veux." So we have "I," "je," and then "veux" for "want." And this "veux" is actually connected to the word "volunteer." A volunteer is the one who wants to do, they are doing something just out of wanting. So we get "je veux" in French, "I want."

speaker: Teacher
text: So "je" is "I" and that's spelled J-E, and then we have "veux" for "want." And "je" and "veux" are actually two different vowel sounds, two slightly different vowel sounds. Although they may sound the same when people speak fast, but we have one sound in "je" and another vowel sound in "veux." So give me again, "I want."

speaker: Teacher
text: Good. And "le" is spelled L-E, just like "je" which is spelled J-E.

speaker: Teacher
text: And that's the same vowel sound there, "le," "je." So give it another try.

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Je veux le gâteau." "I want the coffee."

speaker: Teacher
text: "Je veux le café." If you want to say it, like "I want it," well, the word for "it" is the same as the word for "the," which was?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Le." But we have it first. We say "I it want." We put "it" before "want" in French. So if we want to say "I want it" in French, we say "I it want." How would that be?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Je le veux." Very good. "I want it." "Je le veux." "You want" is "tu veux." "Tu veux."

speaker: Teacher
text: Now, depending on the accent in French, and also depending on your ear, you might hear something like a CH to your ear here. It might sound like "tu" a little bit or maybe like a "tU" with a little bit of an S in Canada, for example. And the U sound here might be a bit unfamiliar for English speakers. "Tu."

speaker: Teacher
text: We point our lips out there when we make that U. So "you want" is "tu veux."

speaker: Teacher
text: How would you say "you want the cake"?

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Tu veux le gâteau?" And you can make that into a question in French just by making it sound like a question. So we just can make a question tone with our voice now to get the question. "Do you want the cake?" How would that be?

speaker: Student
text: Tu veux... Tu veux le gâteau?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Tu veux le gâteau?" How would you say "you want it"?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Tu le veux?" Very good. "Do you want it?"

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. Just with your voice now. "Tu le veux?"

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. So we've seen, we can pull some words into French or back into French from Latin English. Words like "café" and also relate words that might seem unrelated, but in fact are related like "veux" for "want" and "volunteer," the one who wants. We can also learn some tricks to convert huge groups of words into French from our Latin English or our French English. Now, whenever we have an I-O-N word in English like "invitation," "opinion," "participation," we can identify this word as coming from Latin by its I-O-N ending, which means it is probably the same in French as most of Latin English came to English through French. So for example, "collection" in French is "collection." "Collection."

speaker: Teacher
text: Now it's spelled the same, but we notice an S sound instead of the sh that we have in English, "collection," and in French, "collection," like with an S. And we also notice that the N is barely heard, barely pronounced, or not heard, but it's not exactly silent. We don't ignore it totally. We do think about that N. We kind of finish there. "Collection," no? Which affects the sounds before, but we don't really hear the N, so "collection."

speaker: Teacher
text: We're like, we're going towards the end, but we don't, we don't get there. But it's not silent as is often said. How might you say "organization"?

speaker: Teacher
text: "Le café." So much more like "le" than "le." "Le café." So we saw how the word for "the" was "le." No? "Le café," "le gâteau." And also that we can use this "le" for "it." But "the collection" is "la," "la collection."

speaker: Teacher
text: This is because French nouns, nouns are words we can put "the" in front of, are considered either masculine or feminine. The word itself rather than the object it refers to has a gender. The masculine nouns go with "le," L-E, and the feminine nouns go with "la," L-A. What was "I want"?

speaker: Teacher
text: So again, we have a "la" word now. We have a feminine word, and we notice that apart from the N on the end, we also don't really hear the N of "con-." "Confirmation." We don't ignore it. We still think about it, but we don't really hear it. "La confirmation."

speaker: Teacher
text: "Tu veux la confirmation?" So we said that the word for "it" is the same as the word for "the." So if you want to say, "I want it," and you mean "the confirmation," "la confirmation," how would you say, "I want it"? "I it want" in French.

speaker: Teacher
text: "Je la veux." Very good. "You want the collection."

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. "Tu veux la collection." "You want it." And we mean "la collection."

speaker: Teacher
text: "Tu la veux?" So we just can make a question tone with our voice now. "Do you want it?" In English, we added "do" there, but we don't need to worry about that for French. "Tu la veux?" Now, you may be thinking, "How will I know whether a word is masculine or feminine?" Or before that, you may be thinking, "Why the hell are words masculine or [laughs] feminine?" Which is also a good question. But it's actually much simpler than it might seem to identify the gender of the word and it isn't random. You will notice how certain endings will show you what gender the word is. So for example, all of the "ion," I-O-N words, "ion" in French, no? Just like "collection," "tradition," "confirmation," all of these go with "la." So how might you say "the reservation"?

speaker: Teacher
text: Good, and the M here is also kind of slight. "La complication." How would you say "opinion"? "Opinion"?

speaker: Teacher
text: Good. "Opinion." If we say "the opinion," as "opinion" starts with a vowel, we will lose the A of "la" so we get L apostrophe, "opinion." So how, how might that sound?

speaker: Teacher
text: Very good. So you notice we get a lot of different types of word with this "ion" pattern related to many different areas of life, and we can access them just through our Latin or French English.
